"...the current implementation simulates the behavior of the PoET algorithm running in a trusted execution environment and is not secure"

That means that I can't use Sawtooth Lake for production environment yet? Do I have to wait for the development team to release a secure implementation? Or is there something I should do in order to deploy Sawtooth Lake securely?

Hi <@U1ENXTQRL>.  Depends on what you want to do.  If you deploy the simulated PoET in a public chain, the key is available to everyone.  In a private deployment you can use your own key and normal protections (e.g. file permissions) would keep the network secure.
The other option is to wrap the poet calls in a trusted compute environment.
Feel free to DM me with your project and I can give you more specific ideas.
Thank you <@U0VKPD6A2>. I'll certainly be writing you a message soon.

we need to get CI running against sawtooth PRs so that we can externalize our PR process completely.  I propose that we take a short-term and a long-term view.  In the short term, we want to duplicate our Jenkins jobs pretty much as-is to some external Jenkins instance and hook it up to github.  Long-term, we want better integration with the LF setup.
<@U1A7EF0S0|mfford> has joined the channel
By short term, I mean ~1-2 weeks
how are you driving Jenkins? we’re using jjb (as I’m sure you and I discussed), but I don’t remember what you’re using
not JJB, just directly input into Jenkins.  Backed by docker with some scripts for creating the appropriate docker images.
it ends up being fairly involved with a lot of jobs

for example, we have one job for each repo for PRs.  then another job per-repo for building master.  there are a lot of dependencies between them because, for example, the PR branch for sawtooth-core uses the output of master branch sawtooth-validator and sawtooth-mktplace to run nose2 tests
so, every PR we stand up validator networks and run through unit and integration tests, so it's not light-weight from a CPU perspective
that said, we only have a couple VMs dedicated to it at the moment
do you foresee eventually getting it into our workflow as impossible? I mainly mean the vagrant spin up / docker spin up that we’re doing right now for fabric
vagrant spins up a VM, on which we run docker instances for the duration

I might not know enough about the particulars to agree to the fabric workflow.  But if you mean, do we want to have input and all get to the same LF/Hyperledger processes, then yes.  I don't see any problem with the vagrant/docker idea at a high-level, sounds perfect.

I also want to get serious in the next week in evaluating moving to gerrit.  <@U1F97K1UJ> will help lead that charge.  what I'm thinking is we move sawtooth-arcade, force ourselves to use it, and see if we like it enough to justify moving away from github (where I perceive as having less community barriers - but that's what I want to learn about)

Heads up - a config PR was merged in which gets rid of txnvalidator.js from the repo by renaming it to txnvalidator.js.example.  git will tell you if you are impacted when you attempt to fetch/rebase.  dev benefit is that txnvalidator.js is no longer tracked in git, so that will make the normal fetch/rebase cycle nicer.  So now if you want to make changes to txnvalidator.js, copy txnvalidator.js.example to txnvalidator.js and edit from there.
Other benefit <@U0YQQRNU8> pointed out to me was if you use the config file you only have to include the settings you are overriding.

<@U1ZUSJHAA>: a more involved "refactoring" would be to move all client-side validation (use of the transaction family's check_valid/apply) to be server-side.  mktclient is the complex use case there, where it maintains state client-side so it can do client-side validation before sending it to the validator. There are some new Validator Config options that allow you to modify the size of the Threadpool that the web api uses.
“WebPoolSize”: 9,
“MaxWebWorkers”: 8
The above will set the web api threadpool size to 9 threads and the maximum that we want to actually be busy to 8.
We always want MaxWebWorkers to be set to at least 1 less than WebPoolSize.
If theses are not put into the config, the Threadpool size defaults to 8 and the max number of works is set to 7

<@U0N3AJSSU> <@U0VKPD6A2>: Are Ripple and Stellar consensus algorithms not based on leader election (unlike bitcoin)?
Hey <@U249P6GBZ>, i think they are a different from bitcoin and pbft
You'd have to talk to <@U0KPYF3PF> though who implemented it
Pbft has a leader that can changed if it's unresponsive or byzantine
And bitcoin uses proof of work for leader election
But with ripple and stellar you have dynamic membership and so I don't think it has a traditional leader election process
<@U0N3AJSSU|kelly> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/kelly/F24AMG2NM/stellar-consensus-protocol.pdf|Slack for Android Upload>
There is the stellar paper if you're feeling bored :)

View-based protocols associate the slots in votes with monotonically increasing view
numbers. Should consensus get stuck on the 𝑖th slot in view 𝑛, nodes recover by agree-
ing that view 𝑛 had fewer than 𝑖 meaningful slots and moving to a higher view number.
Ballot-based protocols associate the values in votes with monotonically increasing bal-
lot numbers. Should a ballot get stuck, nodes retry the same slot with a higher ballot,
taking care never to select values that would contradict prior stuck ballots.
This work takes a ballot-based approach, as doing so makes it easier to do away with
the notion of a distinguished primary node or leader. For example, leader behavior can
be emulated [Lamport 2011b].
And

the two main
techniques to guarantee termination assuming synchrony do not directly apply in the
FBA model: PBFT [Castro and Liskov 1999] chooses a leader in round-robin fashion,
which is not directly applicable when nodes do not agree on membership. (Possibly
something along the lines of priority in Section 6.1 could be adapted.) The Byzan-
tine Generals protocol [Lamport et al. 1982] relays messages so as to compensate for
ill-behaved nodes saying different things to different honest nodes, an approach that
cannot help when nodes depend on distinct ill-behaved nodes in their slices.
From what I understand the stellar protocol tries to leverage the throughput of pbft with the dynamic membership of proof of work
Other consensus mechanisms that attempt this include honeybadgerbft and scp (scalable consensus protocol)

I looked into the _preparetransactionlist() function in journal_core.py,  found a question about the transaction A depending on B. The case is that B is invalid, and it is deleted in TransactionStore when validator prepares the last pending block. Then validator prepares the current pending block, invokes  _preparetransaction() to handle A, because A depends on B, and B couldn't be found in TransactionStore, then invokes request_missing_txn to request B,  we know B is deleted, couldn't get it. So A becomes a dead transaction, couldn't be deleted, just wait until forever. How we could handle this case?

One solution, we don't delete invalid transactions immediately, just change the status of transaction to invalid. So B is invalid, could be found in TransactionStore. and A depends on B, A is invalid too. We deleted invalid transactions after an  elapse of sometime.
My sawtooth members, what do you think about this case?

<@U1ZUSJHAA> - I have a local branch which a fix for that, the approach I took is to keep track of the 'age' of a transaction - defined as the number of blocks it has been in the pending queue - and delete it if it's over some threshold

Hi there, I understand the Validator Network Launcher is available for running multiple instances of txnvalidator on a single virtual machine, but I'm keen to try and set up multiple VMs instead, so was wondering if someone might be able to provide some quick advice for setting up a validator network using multiple VMs? So far I've configured a private network of vagrant VMs all able to communicate with each other (on separate private-address IPs, separate host ports), but have been a little unsure as to how to configure each one's txnvalidator.js properly (i.e get them to listening to each other over Sawtooth).
Specifically, what should the "LedgerURL" and "Listen" entries look like in each machine?  (not sure where should they point :confused: )
<@U21HV589Z> - the first node you launch will need to be a special 'genesis' node.  You can set Genesis to true in the config file or provide --genesis command line argument
<@U21HV589Z> - LedgerURL can be a list of URLs and can point to all other nodes or some subset.  at a minimum you want the genesis node in that list.
Ah excellent! Yep that makes sense (completely missed that LedgerURL was a list) - with "Listen", should that refer to the node's address itself?

For Listen, you want to bind to the ip available to the other nodes.  you need both the gossip and http statements (as in the txnvalidator.js.example).  alternatively, you can bind to 0.0.0.0 (all interfaces) and specify the Endpoint section of the config for each node.  Usually, I'd do Listen unless there is NAT involved.
bgattas: note in the config, you actually set LedgerURL: ["http://", "......", "...."]. so it's actually a list in the json.
you will need to also set NodeName to something unique for each validator
also, if you want to be able to do any restarting, make sure to pre-generate the node's keys
"KeyFile" : "{key_dir}/{node}.wif"
that file
you can use 'sawtooth keygen' to generate it
(use -h - the usage is pretty simple)

How is the data model of the ledger? For example, Fabric has a Key, with value and version, is the same in Sawtooth? Thanks

We’re working on the data model, so it is in flux. We have two main stores that are in memory. They are key-value stores but one can do lookups based on attributes on the value: sawtooth-core/validator/journal/object_store. For persistence we use a Python module named Shelve that stores binary files, but we are working on other implementations such as Lightning database.

<@U231ZGXDG> and anyone else trying to interface with mktplace without using the provided python client the update model for mktplace has changed. Each Transaction doesn’t have an Update, but now has an Updates array. Inside the Updates array, there is a hash where one key must be ‘UpdateType’. The UpdateTypes are specified in the mktplace/transactions/* files and for example to register a participant the UpdateType would be ‘RegisterParticipant’ or to register an assettype the UpdateType is ‘RegisterAssetType’. If there are any questions on mktplace, just ping me on slack or post here.

text: Is there any plane to implement the security of protocol spec for the sawtooth, like  membership services of fabric?

Transaction families often have their own permissioning.  Authorizations happen on the chain.  Did you have a certain kind of mechanism in mind that you don't see in e.g. Marketplace?  I don't recall fabric's system assumes there's a central authority.
<@U1ZUSJHAA>  Thanks!
<@U1ZUSJHAA> I commented on the PR. I think we need something different to fix the issue.

Commentary. Looking the object model in the  family examples, I miss a smart contract language, because to define the objects, their relations and the restrictions, is a little hard such as is doing. Did you think about that?

<@U0VKPD6A2> The first question of the permissioning is:
I looked into the code of sawtooth, but I couldn't find the code of verifying the signature of transaction. I did a test: I changed transaction['Nonce'] after signing the transaction, then posted the transaction (./bin/xo create game000). But the validation of server passed, didn't throw an error. What's wrong with this or did I make a mistake?
<@U1L6PRGTF> OK, I'll update the PR.

<@U1ZUSJHAA> signature verification is in signed object.  The current model is when a transaction is checked, the parent method for check_valid() is invoked along with any check_valid() defined by the transaction family.  Historically this was called is_valid() and SignedObject class kept that method signature.  So all transactions call SignedObject.is_valid() which verifies the signature.  
If you found a way to modify a transaction and it still passes verification it would be great if you could write up the reproduction case so we can fix that.

<@U0VKPD6A2> Yes, I know SignedObject.is_valid() calls SignedObject.verify_signature(). But the default value of parameter of originatorid is None, so the line of 'return originatorid is None or recovered_id == originatorid' in SignedObject.verify_signature() always return true.
I did a test as follow:
I added a line 'transaction['Nonce'] = time.time()' at  "<https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/core/sawtooth/client.py#L62>". The line I added
 could modify a transaction.
Then I ran './bin/xo create game000' command, it created game000 successfully, the transaction still passes verification.

<@U216ML5MM|witwiki> has joined the channel
<@U1A7EF0S0> The method I described in the proposal could also fix the bug of XoTransaction in <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-9> .
I appended content in the proposal, please take a look.

<@U1ZUSJHAA> Thanks for the proposal. What we ended up going with is adding self.public_key to SignedObject. When verify signature is called it checks the expected public_key against the the originator_public_key that is generated from the serialized object and the signature. If they differ, the signed_object (transaction) has been modified and is not valid. This fixes all transaction families since SignedObject is the superclass to all transactions.    Thanks again for pointing out this issue.

<@U2LH2TFTP> <@U1ZUSJHAA> : perhaps rather than offering individual commands or instructions, it would help for me to explain what is going on.  Initial connectivity is used, among other things, for ledger transfer.  The current behaviour is that a validator will gate on establishing initial connectivity before fully assuming the role of a validator that can provide ledger transfers to other nodes.  The initial validator already has the ledger, including the prefabricated genesis block.  We can't afford to have  it to gate on finding other validators in order to obtain something that it already has (and that no other validator would have at this point during bootstrap), so we set its initial connectivity to zero so that it may begin to provide it's ledger/journal to other validators immediately.

So, this setting has the feeling of being a substitute for the "GenesisLedger" argument of yore.  This fact is both is artificial, and hopefully temporary.  Now that the genesis block is created ahead of time, before starting any validator, it is possible for us to begin to develop side channels through which the genesis block might be distributed to a network before starting even a single validator.

However, for the present time, it is the case that the initial validator, who has the genesis block ready to hand, must have the setting "InitialConnectivity: 0 in their configuration file, and all other validators should set this to a number greater than zero, or omit it entirely from the configuration (in which case it will become 1 in the current code base).

The UI for the marketplace transaction family is now open source.  You’ll find in: <https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/tree/master/extensions/mktplace/navigator>.  

To give some context:

MarketPlace Navigator is a hosted UI for the MarketPlace Transaction
Family. It consists of three major pieces: a single page app, a server
backend, and a syncing tool for synchronizing block state with the
navigator's database.

The Single Page App

The single page app is a ClojureScript app (with some plain JavaScript
dependencies), which provides client-side transaction signing capabilities.
A user of the system generates a WIF key in the browser, which they can save
locally. A user can create most MarketPlace objects via the UI, including
participants, assets, holdings and sell offers.

The Server Backend

The server is a Node.js application, which uses RethinkDB for its
storage needs. It provides API's to create richer representation of the
marketplace objects, in order to improve the user experience. It also
acts as a pass-through for transactions being submitted to a validator.
Any transaction successfully submitted will be recorded, giving history
of any failures that may occur during block construction.

The Synchronization Tool

The synchronization tool is a python script that bridges the gap between
block store contents and a RethinkDB database instance. It reads block
deltas from a validator, and creates block store snapshots, essentially
providing an immutable history of the block state.

The originator_public_key is recovered from the signature, while the public_key is sent along with the transaction. If they are different (and nobody tampered with the data) it means that the data changed. One way this happens is that the keys inside the Updates must be strict upper camel case so ObjectId not ObjectID. If you have something off it will change it and your data will have changed and so your key will fail signature verification.

text: I think there are a couple people looking into it, but it is a broad task and there is room for many suggestions.  Some people will be looking at it holistically so the test suite is designed for coverage without redundancy.  But complementary to that is looking for the redundancy that exists today and removing it. I think small PRs could be helpful here.

<@U1ZUSJHAA> - there are several things we would like to do with tests.  some of them are: 1) move to a test suite approach, where each test suite is made up of tests; the tests may exist in multiple test suites; 2) start supporting the new 'tng' code just merged into master (and still very much in-progress) which requires running multiple processes per validator; 3) for the new transaction processors, devise a testing approach so we can test them in isolation; for example, testing the python inkey or java intkey transaction processors without launching a validator.  4) increase the granularity of our tests, such that it's obvious what the test is intended to cover specifically; many of the existing tests do more than one thing; 5) implement a better library (part of txnintegration) which reduces test code and makes it clearer; for example, maybe having a futures-based approach, where when you send a transaction, you get back a futures object and can use it to check the status of the transaction, with all the polling code, etc. hidden from the test.  future = client.send_txn(...);  ... if (future.done()) {}

<@U1ZUSJHAA>  - to get there, we are consolidating management code under sawtooth.manage package, which 'sawtooth cluster' CLI uses, so we can use the same management framework for both CLI and tests.  So a good entry point into this would be to play around with the 'sawtooth cluster' command and help make it more robust.  Several of us are looking at that, but the more eyes/help on that the better.  Put a note here if you are working on a specific bug and we can try and not duplicate effort.  Very interested in squashing any bugs that throw unhelpful exceptions - for example, I was looking at one earlier where if the docker command doesn't exist it throws an exception - things like that.
like <@U0VKPD6A2> suggested, smaller PRs probably best since there will be activity here from multiple people
<@U0VKPD6A2> <@U0YQQRNU8> I got them, thanks for your detailed information. I'll look into it, and participate in it.

hi everyone. I am just getting started with Sawtooth.  Is there documentation available for running sawtooth validators in a trusted execution environment like the SGX? I am reading from the sawtooth main page that the current release simulates the behavior of PoET since it assumes running outside of TEE. My question is how will the setup differ if I am going to be running on a SGX enabled device.

Hi, PoET has a simulated enclave in it. A TEE implementation would replace that simulated enclave with whatever construct it requires, but the algorithm remains the same. The relying code (the rest of the validator) is all encapsulated behind the consensus interface so there should be no 'integration' changes to support a TEE module.

can we run sawtooth  on non intel processors

<@U2JD3UMEU> - yes, with the exception of the SGX implementation of PoET.  The SGX PoET implementation requires an SGX enclave but there is a simulator (PoET simulator) which we use when testing (for example, on networks on AWS).  The simulator isn't appropriate for production though, as the pieces it simulates are important to the security of the algorithm. Consensus is pluggable but most of the effort to date has been around PoET and the PoET simulator.

hi.. I am trying to understand the WaitTimer class `sawtooth-core/validator/sawtooth_validator/consensus/poet0/wait_timer.py` . I see a bunch of attributes  ```Attributes:
        WaitTimer.minimum_wait_time (float): The minimum wait time in seconds.
        target_wait_time (float): The target wait time in seconds.
        initial_wait_time (float): The initial wait time in seconds.
        certificate_sample_length (int): The number of certificates to
            sample for the population estimate.
        fixed_duration_blocks (int): If fewer than FixedDurationBlocks
            exist, then base the local mean on a ratio based on
            InitialWaitTime, rather than the history.
        WaitTimer.poet_enclave (module): The PoetEnclave module to use for
            executing enclave functions.
        WaitTimer.previous_certificate_id (str): The id of the previous
            certificate.
        WaitTimer.local_mean (float): The local mean wait time based on the
            history of certs.
        WaitTimer.request_time (float): The request time.
        WaitTimer.duration (float): The duration of the wait timer.
        WaitTimer.signature (str): The signature of the timer.
        serialized_timer (str): A serialized version of the timer.

    """
I am trying to understand the difference between intial wait time and target wait time , request_time and duration.. and how it works..
Also we are  calculating the local mean wait time based on the certificate history.. what is the need for a local mean wait time based on certificate history?..
<@U3TKE8X3M|bjorn> has joined the channel
<@U24M29R4G>: good questions
let me take a crack at them

as you probably know, PoET is based on performing a fair leader election by running trusted code in SGX enclaves on participating nodes. Once the prior block is committed, the race for the right to claim the new block begins. Validator nodes all generate their own wait timers at the start of this process.
Wait timers are random times to wait for each validator generated from an exponential random distribution with identical seed values (which are calculated from data from the previous block)
The process of calculating these inputs is deterministic across all validators. The only thing that differs is the random wait time that is produced.

Out of all the validators, one validator will naturally have the lowest wait time. Once its timer expires (again, via trusted attestable execution inside the SGX enclave), it publishes a wait certificate demonstrating proof of all of this and publishes the block out to the network.

initial_wait_time deals with blockchain startup. If you look at the function that deterministically calculates the local mean — WaitTimer.compute_local_mean(), you will see that for a certain number of blocks ( < fixed_duration_blocks) a fixed formula is used to calculate local mean. After fixed_duration_blocks is reached, the local mean shifts to become a driven by the population estimate of the network. Again, this is based on data on the block chain and will be deterministic for all validators working off the same block.
you can see how this works in WaitTimer.population_estimate()

The target wait time is the desired inter-block duration that you’d like the network to converge on. I believe we use 30 seconds as the default. As the population of the network grows, the local mean is modified so that the exponential random distribution is centered around the target wait time.
The certificate history is used as a source of the estimated size of the network based on the diversity of block claimants
<@U24M29R4G> also some example settings here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/validator/etc/txnvalidator.js.example#L20>

attachments.title: hyperledger/sawtooth-core
attachments.text: sawtooth-core - Core repository for Sawtooth Lake Distributed ledger

text: the difference between initial and target times is because the validators haven't had a chance to estimate the size of the network until a few blocks go by.
also noteworthy for the near term is that all nodes on a network need to use the same settings.
If validators A and B have different initial or target times they won't agree with each other.
In coming versions these kinds of settings will be implicit on joining the network and won't be left to individual validator configuration.
